answerText: abacus [or counting frame; prompt on foreign language equivalents such as "schoty" or "suanpan" or "soroban" or "jupan" or "supan" or "jusan" or "nepohualtzintzin"][10] The abacists spread of these mathematical symbols to Europe. Leonardo Fibonacci argued that they were better for commerce and calculations than Roman numerals in his Liber Abaci.
heading: Penn Bowl |2014 | 1 | 6 | Science | Math | College
subject: Science
question: Question: After seeing his Russian captors use the schoty version of this device, Jean-Victor Poncelet reintroduced it to Western Europe. For 10 points each: [10] Name this device that gave its name to a namesake group that opposed the efforts of algorists. The Russian schoty used horizontal wires, but East Asian versions like the Chinese suanpan used vertical ones.
